seg.seg: all the way from the city of Vārāṇāsi (to) the Māgadha country
... going he went to the Pāṣāṇaka Hill. Here now (by gods) ...
... with the ..., relying on the three Smṛtyupasthānas,
... || Having heard this, Bādhari the Brahim ... (of) the Pāṣāṇaka Hill
... hope cut off. With his body trembling, with a sorrowful voice and weeping he says:
... (In the ...gati [tune].) || In order to remove sickness, old age, and death, I practiced austerities,
... unable to go. Far away is the teacher who frees from sorrows. The wish to see him (is) not (fulfilled).
... I will die (without being able to see the Buddha-god the teacher.) 1. || The god says: Bādhari, do not be sorrowful. It is not (in the nature) of the Buddha-god the teacher (to be far away).
... having passed through (innumerable) worlds, (he will come) to his devotees ...
... having shown mercy, after an instant, the devotees’ ...
You have to be (confident). Having spoken in this way, right away (the god) disappeared.
(recollecting the Buddha’s) virtues, (Bādhari spent) the night ...
In the Maitreyasamiti-Nātaka, composed by (the Vaibhāṣika Arya)-candra, (called) ‘Bādhari (the Brahmin’s performing a sacrifice’)
... the (first) act has come to an end. || This book ...
... and ... āk the čor. May we all become Buddhas! ||

p.note: Only two third of the recto side are covered with writing, the leftmost third is left blank. There is a vertical decoration running from top to bottom at the start of the lines, seemingly with an akṣara ‹ktoṃ› on top. This decoration is indicated with an "X" in the transliteration, but it is not indicated in the transcription. A similar decoration recurs in another manuscript, in b, colophon of a chapter of the Maitreyāvadānavyākaraṇa), where there are two columns, with a blank space in between. The lines of the text start to the left of the blank space and continue on the right. Here in our text, we have only the right-end column. Every line looks as if it were complete, but in fact there must be something more, because grammatically the sentence is not complete. Unfortunately we cannot find the continuation anywhere.
This fragment contains part of the first act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami I, 16a14-16b (end). Lines b5-6 contain the colophon of act I. See also 193-4.
The translation and the following commentary are adapted from 66.

Here only ñä is left. According to MaitrHami 1, 16 a21-22, Buddha-god was worshipped by gods and men. Therefore, ñä must be in some way associated with ñkät, maybe the beginning of the obl. pl. ñäktas.

ime, equal to Skt. smṛti-; ṣtmāṣlune, verbal substantive for the causative of käly- “to stand”. These two words give the translation of Skt. smṛty- upasthāna-, Chinese nianchu.There are four smṛtyupasthānāni. Cf. MaitrHami 1, 16 a20-21.
pāṣānak ṣulis: so to be completed. According to MaitrHami 1, 16 a25-27, Bādhari was disappointed at the great distance to Pāṣāṇaka Hill.
gatinaṃ: stanza of probably 21 (8/7/6) + 21 (id.) + 18 (9/9) + 13 (7/6) syllables. Therefore, the name of the tune should be restored as pañcagatinaṃ, see : b5.
Read (wä)lläsmār, complete form, 1st sg. middle of the present of wäl- “to die”. Cf. MaitrHami 1, 16 b6f.
korisyo, so to be completed: “by myriads” (Skt. koṭi-), cf. “numberless” in the Uy. translation.
X: a vertical decoration; see also the remarks above.

kṣaṇaṃ must mean: “in no time”, “in a trice”, in German “im Nu”; loanword from Skt. kṣaṇa. The Uy. version, MaitrHami 1, 16 b14f, reads: “After showing mercy to the devotees, the Buddha-god instantly came back to his original residence.”
kälko: according to MaitrHami 1, 16 b13-14: “After showing mercy to numberless beings.”
According to MaitrHami 1, 16 b25: “Bādhari wept the whole night through”. The German translation of 54, Tafel 14: “In dem er (Tag) und Nacht weinte” is surely wrong.
cor is identical to čor, Chinese (pinyin) chuò (Giles, Karlgren [295c] cho = pinyin zhuò), a Turkish title.
